title: Too many colleges aren’t telling student parents this valuable piece of information, agency says
text:
College students with kids could be missing out on money to defray childcare costs, a new report says.

Some schools aren’t publicizing the federal funds, and the Department of Education isn’t encouraging the schools to spotlight the subsidy either, according to the U.S. Government Accountability Office.

Officials at the watchdog agency said Thursday that 40 of 62 unidentified college websites they examined didn’t mention there’s an option to include a childcare allowance in financial aid calculations.

Schools aren’t required to disclose the possibility students can tap the funding, but the omission matters, the report said.

If student parents use childcare subsidies, that might free up more loan money they can use for their schooling, the report explained.

“Federal student aid can be an important resource available to help student parents — who have fewer financial resources than other students — pay for child care while enrolled in school, but only if students are aware of the option to increase aid to help cover child care cost,” the GAO report said, noting that parents with kids face a greater risk of dropping out.

Education Department officials should “encourage” schools to tell students about the program, the report urged.

Yet Education Department officials believe it would be “inappropriate to indiscriminately encourage all schools to encourage student parents to borrow additional loans without considering a student’s individual financial circumstances,” the report said.

The agency retorted it was just asking for student parents to get a heads up on the option.

The program at issue, Child Care Access Means Parents in School, helped approximately 3,300 students with their childcare costs during the 2016-2017 school year. The median monthly payment was $160, the report noted.

Childcare costs can be a significant financial burden, even for those who are done with college. One month of care at a child-care center now averages about $850 and the prices keep climbing, according to one recent analysis.

Student parents accounted for 22% of the entire college student body during the 2015-2016 school year. Parents on campus are typically older, an average of 33 years old, compared to their childless counterparts, who average 24 years old. Almost three quarters (71%) of student parents are mothers, the report said.

Just over half of undergraduate student parents (52%) dropped out during the 2003-2004 school year, compared to the 32% of students without kids who dropped out.

The GAO report didn’t delve into why so many colleges are skipping the mention of money for childcare. But it did note that those who don’t advertise the funding don’t disburse many child-care allowances. GAO officials interviewed staff at seven colleges that didn’t advertise. “Just two of them reported that they had provided any dependent care allowances in recent years,” the report said.

The watchdog office has spotted other gaps on college campuses. Earlier this year, a GAO report said approximately two million students might not be aware they’re eligible for food stamps.
description: More than 20% of the U.S.’s college students are parents.
